body:
- `nvim --version`: VIM v0.2.1-272-gfe476ed (on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/6816 to fix scrolling problems on master), but I do not remember not having this problem
- Vim (version: ) behaves differently? could not check, no vim available
- Operating system/version: Kubuntu 16.10
- Terminal name/version: Alacritty / rxvt-unicode / konsole
- `$TERM`: xterm-256color

### Actual behaviour

When a big file is opened and modified for a long time, the scrolling gets laggier and laggier. I tried to narrow it down to a plugin / action (over the course of a few months), but in the end what "solves" it is switching to `norelativenumber`.

I tried to profile the script times (with `profile func / file *`) but nothing seems out of place. Syntax parsing is not especially slow. There aren't any autocommands on `CursorMoved` but for [neomake](https://github.com/neomake/neomake), [airline](https://github.com/vim-airline/vim-airline) and [syntastic](https://github.com/vim-syntastic/syntastic), but disabling those plugins did not help.

To sum it up, I open some big file and work on it for a long time, and scrolling is getting laggier and laggier over time. I noticed that the more folds are opened, the laggier it gets. Also, it is "per buffer" (a newly opened buffer will not have the problem unless I spend a long time on it). Finally, `set norelativenumber` instantly solves the problem. Setting `relativenumber` back will make it as laggy as before I disabled it.

Once the lagging is noticeable, I tried switching the filetype to no avail (to remove the possibility of bad syntax file), disabling all plugins that can be dynamically disabled, but in the end `set norelativedelta` is the trigger.

Also (to be clear), the "lag" is actually my CPU running 100%, and it also happens in insert mode, though the easiest and most annoying proof is scrolling.

### Expected behaviour

Not such a huge performance difference between `relativenumber` and `norelativenumber`

### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`

**Edit :** I understand there may not be enough information to solve this, and I can live without `relativenumber`. I will try to narrow it down by trimming my init.vim but this may take some days / weeks

**Edit 2 :** Finally narrowed down the cause of the problem, it was the [indentLine](https://github.com/Yggdroot/indentLine) (detailed report [here](https://github.com/Yggdroot/indentLine/issues/58#issuecomment-314718710)). I do not really understand how I missed it since it never appeared in any report (syntime / profile), but removing it totally solved it (though there still is a difference between using `set relativenumber` and `set norelativenumber`)

comment_data.body: It may be related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2401
Going to treat this like https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/6071. Externalizing won't help TUI, but it's the lowest-hanging fruit.
Should I keep trying to investigate ? I'm still puzzled over the fact that there is some sort of "over time" factor

'relativenumber' in your case is probably just exacerbating the actual problem, but you don't notice the actual problem until 'relativenumber' adds gas to the fire.

In your case it sounds like a problematic `foldexpr` or `foldmethod`.

`relativenumber` slows down (n)vim because it (unnecessarily) forces the screen to be redrawn on every cursor move. And the redraw needs to recompute syntax highlighting for the whole screen which is the main slowdown - actually, the vim docs suggest `rnu` as a "good" way to profile syntax performance. I guess folds add to that too (but in most files I edit the syntax highlighting is already enough to basically make `rnu` unuseable). See also https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/1735.

> Externalizing won't help TUI, but it's the lowest-hanging fruit.

I don't really know how terminal drawing works, but unless it is very limited I believe this would also help in the TUI. The number column and the text don't really intersect* so it should be possible to draw them independently, which should basically give equal performance of `nu` and `rnu` (modulo drawing the number column).

*) if `n` is not in `cpoptions`

I am pretty sure this issue is [vim/vim#1735](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/1735) as noted by @yagebu.

Should I open that same *Feature Enhancement* request here at the Neovim issue tracker? Is that poor form?

Anyway, *vim#1735* (syntax highlight caching) is my personal number one most desired Vim or Neovim feature enhancement. I also suspect, nasty to implement and many a corner case (though I could be wrong I hope).
I'm fairly certain Bram is working on syntax caching, so we will merge that when it lands upstream.
Can't also just the number column be redrawn without redrawing the rest of the window?

@justinmk, very nice indeed. I hope your belief is right, it would help both Vim and Neovim `relativenumber` users a lot.

@bfredl, see @yagebu  answer just above, it seems the number column is not a separate part of the screen, but rather a part of a line; so if a line changes in any way (e.g even just in the number column) then the whole line needs to be re-evaluated. Terminals probably are line-based I assume?

@bluz71 linenumbers are rendered first in `win_line`, so I don't think it should be too hard. (well, after signs, but shouldn't hurt much to redraw them too) Only issue I could think of: with `linebreak`, need to cache the vertical size of buffer lines. (or can probably just do whatever `gj` does, even recalculating should be a lot cheaper than actually rerendering the entire screenful).

@bfredl, I was going on hearsay; very easily I could be misinformed. You grok the source code, I've never seen it.

By all means dig around and experiment, `relativenumber` is a scroll performance killer. Any and everything that can speed it up would be appreciated; like really appreciated.

> I'm fairly certain Bram is working on syntax caching, so we will merge that when it lands upstream.

Is Bram working on this?
The relevant information (for re-rendering number column only) is stored in `wp->w_lines`: `wl_num` for the buffer line numbers and `wl_size` for the physical screen lines the buffer line occupied.

@bfredl,

Do you believe that a fix may be implemented in Neovim? Your hints do suggest that.

Or is it a case of waiting for a fix in Vim via the existing [vim/vim#1735](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/1735) issue as noted by @justinmk?

Either way, I can report the `relativenumber` performance issues are still very much a real thing.

[(#8320) Plan for extending the UI protocol and externalizing window layout and control](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8320) is a very exciting prospect.

Good luck to all involved; hopefully `relativenumber` can be externalised.

Vim commit [bd9a53c](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/bd9a53c06c8869ad811cb3dd01a309c9be7d7a63) (patch 8.1.0374) implements a `relativenumber` optimisation, _only redraw the number column, not all lines_.

I have updated and tested, and indeed when scrolling within a page, with `relativenumber` enabled, is now smooth.

I don't know whether externalizing `relativenumber` will achieve the same effect. If not, then I recommend merging [bd9a53c](https://github.com/vim/vim/commit/bd9a53c06c8869ad811cb3dd01a309c9be7d7a63) for the next Neovim release. It really does make a big difference for the better.
@bluz71 We already merged that. Did you test Nvim HEAD?
Um. Well it would help to know if you see an effect (in Nvim). Because I didn't notice much difference (in Vim nor Nvim).

It tended to happen only with certain languages with super-heavy syntax highlighters (such as Ruby), on slow computers and with `regexpengine=2`.

Also, I've generally found Neovim faster at scrolling within a page than Vim, for whatever reason.

Since I use Neovim for production coding I don't want to move to an unstable version.

The patch works in Vim, I just did a Jenny Craig before and after. It will benefit Neovim, so it is great that it has been merged.

milestone.description: Low priority. Not planned for the current target, may be reassigned.
milestone.title: backlog

title: API/UI: externalize 'relativenumber'
